meanings.def: to such a great degree
examples: Don't look so angry.
There's no need to worry so.
Why has it taken so long?
That wasn't so bad, was it?
so… (that)… She spoke so quietly (that) I could hardly hear her.
What is it that's so important it can't wait five minutes?
He was so impressed that he jumped up and down with excitement.
She gets so caught up in her fame that she neglects her true friends.
It was so incredibly cheap it was unbelievable.
so… as to do something I'm not so stupid as to believe that.
(formal, especially British English) Would you be so kind as to lock the door when you leave?
You should sew that hole up before it gets any bigger.
It is unsurprising that the Beatles were so successful.
Why would farmers want to sow GM seeds?

meanings.def: very; extremely
examples: I'm so glad to see you.
The girls looked so pretty in their summer dresses.
I was pleased that so many people turned up.
We have so much to do.
It's so good to have you back.
We've worked so hard to get to this point.
They came so close to winning.
You're going to Harvard! That's so great!
Their attitude is so very English.
The article was just so much (= nothing but) nonsense.
I am so pleased with this new book.
(British English) He sat there ever so quietly.
(British English) I do love it so.

meanings.def: not to the same degree
examples: I haven't enjoyed myself so much for a long time.
I have never felt so humiliated in my entire life.
It wasn't so good as last time.
It's not so easy as you'd think.
He was not so quick a learner as his brother.
It's not so much a hobby as a career (= more like a career than a hobby).
(disapproving) Off she went without so much as (= without even) a ‘goodbye’.

meanings.def: used to show the size, amount or number of something
examples: The fish was about so big (= said when using your hands to show the size).
There are only so many (= only a limited number of) hours in a day.

meanings.def: used to refer back to something that has already been mentioned
examples: ‘Is he coming?’ ‘I hope so.’
‘Did they mind?’ ‘I don't think so.’
If she notices, she never says so.
I might be away next week. If so, I won't be able to see you.
We are very busy—so much so that we won't be able to take time off this year.
Programs are expensive, and even more so if you have to keep altering them.
I hear that you're a writer—is that so (= is that true)?
George is going to help me, or so he says (= that is what he says but I am not sure if I believe him).
They asked me to call them and I did so (= I called).
She leaked the story to the media and, in so doing, helped bring down the president.
He thinks I dislike him but that just isn't so.

meanings.def: also
examples: Times have changed and so have I.
‘I prefer the first version.’ ‘So do we.’
Temperatures are rising in Canada, and so too are the annual blueberry harvests.

meanings.def: used to agree that something is true, especially when you are surprised
examples: ‘You were there, too.’ ‘So I was—I'd forgotten.’
‘There's another one.’ ‘So there is.’

meanings.def: used, often with a negative, before adjectives and noun phrases to emphasize something that you are saying
examples: He is so not the right person for you.
That is so not cool.

meanings.def: used, especially by children, to say that what somebody says is not the case and the opposite is true
examples: ‘You're not telling the truth, are you?’ ‘I am, so!’

meanings.def: used when you are showing somebody how to do something or telling them how something happened
examples: Stand with your arms out, so.
(literary) So it was that he finally returned home.

meanings.def: used at the end of a list to show that it continues in the same way
examples: We discussed everything—when to go, what to see and so on.

meanings.def: used to give an important extra reason why something is true
examples: His achievement is remarkable; all the more so because he had no help at all.

meanings.def: used after a number, an amount, etc. to show that it is not exact
examples: There were twenty or so (= about twenty) people there.
We stayed for an hour or so.

meanings.def: with the intention of doing something
examples: We went early so as to get good seats.

meanings.def: used to show that you accept something and will not try to change it or cannot change it
examples: If he doesn't want to be involved, then so be it.

meanings.def: used to show that you have finished talking about something
examples: So much for the situation in Germany. Now we turn our attention to France.

meanings.def: used to suggest that something has not been successful or useful
examples: So much for that idea!

meanings.def: in such a way that
examples: The programme has been so organized that none of the talks overlap.

idioms.def: used at the end of a list to show that it continues in the same way
examples: We discussed everything—when to go, what to see and so on.

idioms.def: used to give an important extra reason why something is true
examples: His achievement is remarkable; all the more so because he had no help at all.

idioms.def: used after a number, an amount, etc. to show that it is not exact
examples: There were twenty or so (= about twenty) people there.
We stayed for an hour or so.

idioms.def: with the intention of doing something
examples: We went early so as to get good seats.

idioms.def: used to show that you accept something and will not try to change it or cannot change it
examples: If he doesn't want to be involved, then so be it.

idioms.def: used to show that you have finished talking about something
examples: So much for the situation in Germany. Now we turn our attention to France.
So much for that idea!
The programme has been so organized that none of the talks overlap.

meanings.def: south; southern
used to show the reason for something
examples: It was still painful, so I went to see a doctor.

meanings.def: used to show the purpose of something
examples: But I gave you a map so you wouldn't get lost!
She worked hard so that everything would be ready in time.

meanings.def: used to show the result of something
examples: Nothing more was heard from him so that we began to wonder if he was dead.

meanings.def: used to introduce a comment or a question
examples: So, let's see. What do we need to take?
So, what have you been doing today?

meanings.def: used to introduce the next part of a story
examples: So after shouting and screaming for an hour she walked out in tears.

meanings.def: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it
examples: So I had a couple of drinks on the way home. What's wrong with that?
‘You've been smoking again.’ ‘So?’

meanings.def: used when you are making a final statement
examples: So, that's it for today.

meanings.def: used in questions to refer to something that has just been said
examples: So there's nothing we can do about it?
‘I've just got back from a trip to Rome.’ ‘So, how was it?’

meanings.def: used to introduce an answer to a question, an explanation or a statement
examples: So, I've been working on a new project.

meanings.def: used when stating that two events, situations, etc. are similar
examples: Just as large companies are having to cut back, so small businesses are being forced to close.

meanings.def: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it
examples: ‘He's fifteen years younger than you!’ ‘So what?’
So what if nobody else agrees with me?

idioms.def: used to show that you think something is not important, especially after somebody has criticized you for it
examples: ‘He's fifteen years younger than you!’ ‘So what?’
So what if nobody else agrees with me?

meanings.def: the fifth note of a major scale
